title: How to Eat in a Yakiniku Restaurant

steps.headline: Check their food menu.
steps.description: Different restaurants offers different specialties but they often have beef,vegetables,seafood and offal.

steps.headline: Order their best sellers and try to do extreme.
steps.description: Ask their best sellers and caught your interest. Most Yakiniku restaurant have Rōsu which are beef loin and chuck slices, Misuji a tender beef meat or you can go extreme by trying pork or beef offal (meat organs) which are really delicious when grilled.

steps.headline: Cleanse your hands.
steps.description: While waiting for the food, find a way to cleanse your hands and try to ask for wet-wipes.

steps.headline: Don't panic.
steps.description: They will serve your orders uncooked. Yes you heard in right, It's raw meat and veggies.

steps.headline: Ask for assistance to turn-on the grill.
steps.description: A restaurant staff will usually turn-on the grill placed on top of the table or embedded but if not, ask for assistance because they know the right temperature.

steps.headline: Grill your food.
steps.description: Using a long chopstick or a metal thong, grill your food and its up to you if you want it well-done or medium rare.

steps.headline: Place it all in a plate.
steps.description: Once cooked, place your food in a plate. Don't leave it on the grill while you are eating because it might burn and be uneatable

steps.headline: Say "Itadakimasu" before eating.
steps.description: It means, "Let's eat!" and a form of saying "thank you " in Japanese etiquette, a similar phrase as 'bon appétit. You're in a Japanese restaurant, might as well try their etiquette.

steps.headline: Try different sauces.
steps.description: Different Yakiniku restaurant have different sauce options and often serve as their trademark.

steps.headline: Pay your bill.
steps.description: Don't leave your meal unpaid. You might be in a big trouble if you do so.
